title: How to Unclog a Drain or Garbage Disposal with Baking Soda & Vinegar

steps.title: Sprinkle ¼ cup (68 g) of baking soda down your clogged drain.
steps.content: Sprinkle ¼ cup (68 g) of baking soda down your clogged drain. Don’t add the vinegar just yet—only add the baking soda at first. [1] X Research source Note: This method also works for garbage disposals. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Pour 1⁄2 c (120 mL) of white vinegar into the drain.
steps.content: Pour 1 ⁄ 2 c (120 mL) of white vinegar into the drain. It might help to funnel the vinegar into the drain, depending on the size of it within your sink or tub. [3] X Research source Alternative: Double the recipe by using ½ cup of baking soda (136 g) and 1 c (240 mL) of white vinegar. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the drain and wait 15 minutes.
steps.content: Cover the drain and wait 15 minutes. Chances are, the mixture will begin to foam and possibly overflow from the drain. [5] X Research source Grab a towel, drain cover, or another similar item to block off the drain as much as possible to keep the baking soda and vinegar solution in the pipe or garbage disposal. Then, give the baking soda and vinegar 15 minutes to work through the clog in your drain. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Pour 2 US qt (1.9 L) of boiling water down your drain.
steps.content: Pour 2 US qt (1.9 L) of boiling water down your drain. The boiling water helps clear away the clog, along with the leftover baking soda and vinegar. [7] X Research source Consider wearing mitts as you handle the hot water candle. Watch out for the steam as you pour the water down the drain, too! [8] X Research source

steps.title: Test the drain and repeat the process if the clog is still there.
steps.content: Test the drain and repeat the process if the clog is still there. Turn on the tap and monitor the drain—does the water cycle away easily, or does there still seem to be a blockage? If the clog persists, repeat the process (steps 1 through 4) and see if anything improves. [9] X Research source What if the clog doesn’t go away? Funnel ½ cup of borax into the drain, along with 2 c (470 mL) of boiling water. If you suspect that hair is causing the clog (like in a bathtub drain), use a hair snake to get rid of it. [10] X Research source When should you try vinegar and baking soda? Give this remedy a try whenever your drain starts to run slower than normal and the blockage is deep enough that you can't pull it out with your hands or a short tool. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Dispose of fats and oils properly.
steps.content: Dispose of fats and oils properly. While many fats and oils appear to be liquified, they can easily solidify and cause problems in your pipes. Instead, let any hot oils and fats cool off completely, and then pour them into a disposable plastic container (like an empty bottle). Throw this in the trash like you would any other piece of garbage. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Install a drain basket or drain guard.
steps.content: Install a drain basket or drain guard . Drain baskets and guards provide an extra line of defense to hair and other debris that can create clogs in your pipes. Every so often, dump out the basket or guard to remove the debris, and then stick it back in the drain. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Pour hot water down your drain once a week.
steps.content: Pour hot water down your drain once a week. Fill your kettle with water, boil it, and pour it down the drain (even if your sink isn’t currently clogged). The weekly hot water flushes may help keep your pipes clear. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Only use cold water with your garbage disposal.
steps.content: Only use cold water with your garbage disposal. Even if you’re careful, there’s a chance that fats and oils can make it down your pipes. Hot water will only serve to melt and liquefy this grease, which can lead to blockages further down the line. [15] X Research source

steps.title: They’re better for the environment.
steps.content: They’re better for the environment. As effective as commercial drain cleaners may be, they’re loaded with harsh chemicals that are harmful to the environment, like lye, sulfuric acid, and/or hydrochloric acid. Eventually, these chemicals can make their way into ecosystems. [16] X Research source

steps.title: They’re not as tough on your pipes.
steps.content: They’re not as tough on your pipes. Commercial drain cleaners are made with heavy-duty chemicals—chemicals that, when used enough, can wreak pretty serious havoc on your pipes. Switching to a less corrosive cleaner (like household agents) can help keep your plumbing in great shape for years to come. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Commercial drain cleaners aren’t great for your health.
steps.content: Commercial drain cleaners aren’t great for your health. Using these commercial products frequently can contribute to health risks, like skin irritation and harm to the nasal passages. Using household cleaning agents like baking soda and vinegar present far less risk. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Yes, but you might need to use it several times.
steps.content: Yes, but you might need to use it several times. Many people agree that the combined power of baking soda and vinegar can be an effective (and all-natural) way to get rid of clogs, but it isn’t 100% foolproof. The combo might not clear away the entire clog at first, so you may need to use multiple courses of baking soda, vinegar, and boiling water to get the results you’re looking for. [19] X Research source Baking soda and vinegar fall on opposite ends of the pH scale, with baking soda being basic and vinegar being acidic. When you combine the two, multiple chemical reactions occur, including one that produces carbon dioxide (hence the foamy bubbles). [20] X Research source The mix of baking soda and vinegar helps to eat through the clog. [21] X Research source
